title: How to Repurpose Old Christmas Lights Into Glitter Decorations

steps.headline: Choose medium to large size Christmas light bulbs.
steps.description: The bulbs need to be a decent size, otherwise they won't look spectacular when glittered. Unscrew then from the light holders and put the rest of the light arrangement to one side for re-purposing in its own right, or for recycling.

steps.headline: Check the light bulbs.
steps.description: Discard any that are cracked, chipped or broken. If they need a clean, give them a wipe down with a damp cleaning cloth. Allow to dry before proceeding.

steps.headline: Work on one bulb at a time.
steps.description: That way, you can fix any mistakes as you go and the glue won't dry out on you while preparing each one. Before starting, lay out a sheet of wax paper on the work space––this will catch the glitter and prevent sticking.

steps.headline: Paint the bulb with craft glue.
Sprinkle the painted bulb with glitter.
steps.description: Rotate slowly to add evenly across the entire surface of the bulb. Choose colors that mean the most to you for celebrating the season. Typical colors include gold, silver, red and green. White for snow is good too, but only use this on white bulbs as the color of the bulb beneath it will show through.

steps.headline: Lay the glittered bulb on the wax paper to dry.
steps.description: As it is drying, start the next and repeat as many times as you need to complete the bulbs.

steps.headline: After drying, pick up each bulb and check the surface.
steps.description: If the glitter is uneven anywhere, do touch ups and dry as before.

text: Preparing the Light Bulbs Choose medium to large size Christmas light bulbs. The bulbs need to be a decent size, otherwise they won't look spectacular when glittered. Unscrew then from the light holders and put the rest of the light arrangement to one side for re-purposing in its own right, or for recycling. Check the light bulbs. Discard any that are cracked, chipped or broken. If they need a clean, give them a wipe down with a damp cleaning cloth. Allow to dry before proceeding. Adding the Glitter Work on one bulb at a time. That way, you can fix any mistakes as you go and the glue won't dry out on you while preparing each one. Before starting, lay out a sheet of wax paper on the work space––this will catch the glitter and prevent sticking. Paint the bulb with craft glue.  Sprinkle the painted bulb with glitter. Rotate slowly to add evenly across the entire surface of the bulb. Choose colors that mean the most to you for celebrating the season. Typical colors include gold, silver, red and green. White for snow is good too, but only use this on white bulbs as the color of the bulb beneath it will show through. Lay the glittered bulb on the wax paper to dry. As it is drying, start the next and repeat as many times as you need to complete the bulbs. After drying, pick up each bulb and check the surface. If the glitter is uneven anywhere, do touch ups and dry as before.
